title: 110_s2471
content: The Act may be cited as the "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" and includes reforms to the USERRA complaint process. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. It requires the Secretary to notify complainants of their rights within 5 days and provide technical assistance upon request. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. Any action required by subsections (d) and (e) with respect to a complaint submitted to the Secretary must be completed within 90 days. Referrals to the Attorney General and special counsel must be made within 15 days of receiving a request. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. Referrals to the Attorney General and special counsel must be made within 15 days of receiving a request. The Secretary shall refer complaints within 90 days, and the Attorney General or Special Counsel must make a decision within 45 days of receiving the referral. The Special Counsel must make a decision within 45 days of receiving a referral to represent a person before the Merit Systems Protection Board. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS WITH RESPECT TO ENFORCEMENT OF USERRA. Expansion of reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement includes amending Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code to include the number of cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve, as well as cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment. The amendment to Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code expands reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement to include cases involving individuals seeking employment or reemployment. This includes reporting on disability-related issues and types of disabilities. The amendment expands reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement to include cases involving individuals seeking employment or reemployment. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel on cases where the Secretary did not meet requirements and received requests for referrals. The reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement have been expanded to include cases of individuals seeking employment or reemployment. The Comptroller General must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel on cases where referrals were not made within the required time periods. The reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement have been expanded to include cases of individuals seeking employment or reemployment. The Secretary will coordinate with other departments to ensure uniform categorization of data and electronic access to case files. Effective immediately, the amendments apply to all required reports. The amendments apply to all required reports under section 4332 after the enactment of this Act.
